standard_metadata.standard_description: Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.

hints.content: To add fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.
Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{70}{100}}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: Two squares, one square divided into ten equal-sized rows. The bottom seven rows are shaded blue. A second square divided into 10 equal-sized rows made up of ten equal-sized squares. The bottom seven rows are shaded blue. An equal sign separates the two squares. Each square has the same area shaded.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{70}{100}}$  So, we can replace $\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}$ with $\blueD{\dfrac{70}{100}}$ in our expression.  $\blueD{\dfrac7{10}}+ \dfrac{13}{100}=\blueD{\dfrac{70}{100}}+ \dfrac{13}{100}$
This is the equivalent expression.  $\blueD{\dfrac{70}{100}}+ \dfrac{13}{100}$
To add fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.
Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: Two squares, one square divided into ten equal-sized rows. The bottom four rows are shaded blue. A second square divided into 10 equal-sized rows made up of ten equal-sized squares. The bottom four rows are shaded blue. An equal sign separates the two squares. Each square has the same area shaded.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$  So, we can replace $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$ with $\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$ in our expression.  $\blueD{\dfrac4{10}}+ \dfrac{47}{100}=\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}+ \dfrac{47}{100}$
This is the equivalent expression.  $\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}+ \dfrac{47}{100}$
To add fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.
Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]    [[☃ image 2]]     $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{10}{100}}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{10}{100}}$  So, we can replace $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ with $\blueD{\dfrac{10}{100}}$ in our expression.  $\blueD{\dfrac1{10}}+ \dfrac{99}{100}=\blueD{\dfrac{10}{100}}+ \dfrac{99}{100}$
This is the equivalent expression.  $\blueD{\dfrac{10}{100}}+ \dfrac{99}{100}$

question.content: A bunny's ears grew $\dfrac{14}{100}\text{ cm}$ last year and $\dfrac4{10}\text{ cm}$ this year.  **What expression can be used to find the total length the bunny's ears grew during the two years?**

hints.content: To find the total amount the bunny's ear grew, we need to add $\dfrac{14}{100}\text{ cm}$ and $\dfrac4{10}\text{ cm}$.
To add the fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.
Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: Two squares, one square divided into ten equal-sized rows. The bottom four rows are shaded blue. A second square divided into 10 equal-sized rows made up of ten equal-sized squares. The bottom four rows are shaded blue. An equal sign separates the two squares. Each square has the same area shaded.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$  So, we can replace $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}}$ with $\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$ in our expression.  $ \dfrac{14}{100} + \blueD{\dfrac4{10}}=  \dfrac{14}{100} + \blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$
The following expression can be used to find the total length the bunny's ears grew.  $\dfrac{14}{100}+\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}$

question.content: A magic bean plant grew $\dfrac{97}{100}\text{ m}$ one minute and $\dfrac9{10}\text{ m}$ the next minute.  **What expression can be used to find the total amount the plant grew during the two minutes?**

hints.content: To find the total amount the plant grew, we need to add $\dfrac{97}{100}\text{ m}$ and $\dfrac9{10}\text{ m}$.
To add the fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.
Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{9}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{90}{100}}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]

The bottom nine rows are shaded blue. An equal sign separates the two squares. Each square has the same area shaded.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{9}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{90}{100}}$  So, we can replace $\blueD{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ with $\blueD{\dfrac{90}{100}}$ in our expression.  $ \dfrac{97}{100} + \blueD{\dfrac9{10}}=  \dfrac{97}{100} + \blueD{\dfrac{90}{100}}$
The following expression can be used to find the total amount the plant grew.  $\dfrac{97}{100}+\blueD{\dfrac{90}{100}}$

question.content: In a snail race, one snail crawled $\dfrac{106}{100}\text{ m}$ in one minute. Another snail crawled $\dfrac8{10}\text{ m}$ in one  minute.  **What expression can be used to find the total distance both snails crawled in the race?**

hints.content: To find the total distance both snails crawled in the race, we need to add $\dfrac{106}{100}\text{ m}$ and $\dfrac8{10}\text{ m}$.
To add the fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.
Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{80}{100}}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{80}{100}}$  So, we can replace $\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}}$ with $\blueD{\dfrac{80}{100}}$ in our expression.  $ \dfrac{106}{100} + \blueD{\dfrac8{10}}=  \dfrac{106}{100} + \blueD{\dfrac{80}{100}}$
The following expression can be used to find the total distance both snails crawled in the race.  $\dfrac{106}{100}+\blueD{\dfrac{80}{100}}$

question.content: Gus ate a stack of two pancakes for breakfast. One pancake was $\dfrac{130}{100}\text{ cm}$ thick and the other pancake was $\dfrac{15}{10}\text{ cm}$ thick.  **What expression can be used to find the total height of the stack?**

hints.content: To find the total height of the two pancakes, we need to add $\dfrac{130}{100}\text{ cm}$ and $\dfrac{15}{10}\text{ cm}$.
To add the fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.

Let's change $\blueD{\dfrac{15}{10}}$ to an equivalent fraction with a denominator of $100$.    [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]   [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{15}{10}}=\blueD{\dfrac{150}{100}}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

The following expression can be used to find the total height of the stack.  $\dfrac{130}{100}+ \blueD{\dfrac{150}{100}}$

question.content: Soshi made two big snowballs for a snowman. One snowball was $\dfrac{4}{10}\text{ m}$ tall and the other snowball was $\dfrac{65}{100}\text{ m}$ tall.  **What expression can be used to find the total height of both snowballs?**

hints.content: To find the total height of the two snowballs, we need to add $\dfrac{4}{10}\text{ m}$ and $\dfrac{65}{100}\text{ m}$.
To add the fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  So, we are looking for an equivalent expression that has common denominators.

The following expression can be used to find the total height of both snowballs.  $\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}+\dfrac{65}{100}$

The following expression can be used to find the total distance the frogs jumped.  $\blueD{\dfrac{30}{100}}+\dfrac{25}{100}$

The following expression can be used to find the total height of both pumpkins.  $\blueD{\dfrac{50}{100}}+\dfrac{41}{100}$

question.content: Joseph is eating his favorite kind of cookie. The cookie part is $\dfrac{9}{10}\text{ cm}$ thick. The frosting part is  $\dfrac{33}{100}\text{ cm}$ thick.  **What expression can be used to find the total thickness of the cookie and frosting?**
